vocabulary.english: verb prefix that means “to be able to”; used with um verb roots (AF(a))
verb prefix that means “to be able to”; used with mag verb roots (AF(a))

contents.markdown: _Maka_- and _makapag_- verbs are second tier verbs that add the nuance “to be able to” to the root. You may remember that _ma_- OF verbs often have the same nuance; _maka_- and _makapag_- can be considered their AF counterparts. There may be some other nuances, but they are less common so we will not cover them in this book.
<u>Traits of Maka- Verbs</u>
All are AF(a) that do not form imperatives.
Normally used with -_um_- verb roots.
<u>Maka- Verb Infinitives </u>
To form the infinitive, add _maka_ to the root of the -_um_- verb.
Ex: maka + root of gumawâ = makagawâ = to be able to do/make
Ex: maka + root of kumain = makakain = to be able to eat
Ex: maka + root of pumuntá = makapuntá = to be able to go
<u>Maka- Verb Aspects</u>
_Maka_- verbs aspects are formed as shown. Notice that it is similar to _ma_- verb aspect formation, with the _ka_ of _maka_ getting repeated in uncompleted and contemplated aspects.

item.english: David was able to make adobo.
Are they able to eat at night?

item.tagalog: Makakapunta kami ni Maria sa Maynila.
item.english: Maria and I will be able to go to Manila.

contents.markdown: <u>Traits of Makapag- Verbs</u>
All are AF(a) that do not form imperatives.
Normally used with _mag_- verb roots.
<u>Makapag- Verb Infinitives </u>
Add _makapag_ before the root; use a dash if the root begins with a vowel
Ex: makapag + root of mag-aral = makapag-aral = to be able to study
Ex: makapag + root of magbigáy = makapagbigáy = to be able to give
Ex: makapag + root of maglutò = makapaglutò = to be able to cook
<u>Makapag- Verb Aspects</u>
_Makapag_-verbs are conjugated as shown. Notice that it is similar to _ma_- verb aspect formation, with _ka_ of _makapag_ getting repeated in uncompleted and contemplated aspects.

item.english: I will be able to cook the lechon.
She would like to be able to study at home.

item.tagalog: Nakapagbigay si Jason ng pagkain sa aso.
item.english: Jason was able to give food to the dog.

contents.markdown: <u>Have you ever...?</u>

In a previous lesson you learned how to ask “Have you ever been to…” using _mapuntahan_, when the focus was on the place. You can use _maka_ verbs to ask “Have you ever…” when the focus is on the actor. Although the literal translation is not exact, the following is a colloquial structure for asking if someone has ever done something:
Naka/nakapag + root + ka + na + ba? (Tag.) = Have you ever verbed? (Eng.)

item.tagalog: Nakapunta ka na ba sa Pilipinas?
item.english: Have you ever been to the Philippines? (lit. Were you able to go to the Philippines already?)

item.tagalog: Hindi pa ako nakakapunta sa Pilipinas.
item.english: I have not ever been to the Philippines.

item.tagalog: Nakapagluto na ba siya ng adobo?
item.english: Has she ever cooked adobo? (lit. Was she able to cook adobo already?)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nakakain ka na ba ng lechon o adobo?
exampleSentences.english: Have you ever eaten lechon or adobo?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nakakapag-aral ang kasama ko ng Ingles sa trabaho niya.
exampleSentences.english: My companion is able to study english at her work.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Makakagawa ako ng sarili kong bahay, kasi talagang mura ito.
exampleSentences.english: I will be able to make my own house, because it is really cheap.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nakapagbigay rin ba sila ni Maria ng bagay na yun sa inyo?
exampleSentences.english: Were she and Maria also able to give you (pl.) that thing?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nakakapunta siya sa Maynila tuwing Mayo, pero hindi sa Cebu.
exampleSentences.english: He is able to go to Manila every May, but not to Cebu.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Makakapagluto si Diego sa lugar na yun, kaya pumunta tayo dun!
exampleSentences.english: Diego will be able to cook in that place, so let's go there!
Where were you able to buy this? How much?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Aling aso ang nakakapaglaro sa pusa sa loob?
exampleSentences.english: Which dog is able to play with the cat inside?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Taga-Seattle si David, kaya makakauwi siya bukas.
exampleSentences.english: David is from Seattle, so he will be able to go home tomorrow.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nandito ang hindi nakapagturo ng basketbol dahil sa ulan.
exampleSentences.english: Here is the one who was not able to teach basketball due to rain.
